awd_titl_txt: Teacher Education for Equitable Mathematics Instruction: An Exploratory Study of Noyce Program Impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Noyce Program, Research Track 4, this partnership between the University of Arizona Main Campus, University of Arizona South Campus, Northern Arizona University, University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and the University of New Hampshire will examine teacher efficacy and persistence.  Noyce programs seek to prepare effective teachers who can provide equitable instruction to diverse populations in high-need districts.  The efficacy part of the study will examine the development of equity-related beliefs, knowledge, and practices of prospective mathematics teachers in five Noyce programs.  The teacher persistence part of the study will characterize study participants' developing senses of autonomy, competence, and relatedness, which are predictors of persistence. This research study will include the participation of approximately 100 prospective teachers from institutions that have recently received Noyce Track 1 awards.  Half of the study participants will be Noyce program participants.  Non-Noyce pre-service teachers in the same programs will serve as the comparison group.  The project will compare findings for Noyce and non-Noyce prospective mathematics teachers.  This development will be examined as it relates to experiences in teacher preparation and induction programs.

This project intends to use an exploratory mixed-methods research design. The investigators propose to explore the following research questions: How do courses and fieldwork impact the development of knowledge and beliefs about equity? How are knowledge and beliefs about equity expressed in teacher practice? Which Noyce program elements are associated with the development of one or more aspects of equitable practice? To answer these questions, data will be collected over four years from project participants across the partnering institutions. Data sources will include surveys, interviews, work samples, and video of classroom instruction. Analysis will be framed by theories of culturally responsive teaching (Gay, 2000; 2002), equity literacy (Gorski, 2014), and Self Determination Theory (Ryan & Deci, 2000). Project outcomes will include important knowledge about the development of equity-related knowledge, beliefs, and practices in mathematics teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research Questions:

How do pre-service teachers' courses and fieldwork impact the development of their knowledge and beliefs about equity?

How are beginning teachers' knowledge and beliefs about equity expressed in their emerging teacher practice?

Which Noyce program elements are associated with the development of one or more aspects of equitable practice? 

Overall, we found teachers attending to multiple dimensions of equity (McGraw et al., 2022; 2024a; 2024b), and particularly attending to the individual needs of learners, recognizing and mitigating constraints limiting access, and focusing on building student confidence and improving math identity (McGraw et al., 2024a). We also found evidence of teachers challenging deficit views, drawing on student language resources, and advocating for students and themselves.

From examination of pre-service teachers' conception of equity (McGraw et al., 2024b; McGraw et al., 2022) we found:

  • Participants associated equity with whether/how students engaged with mathematics, and with an approach to teaching mathematics, they saw equity as both a personal quality and systemic concern.
  • Participants thought about equity as building confidence/success, learning about and connecting with students, and attending to biases and mindset, as well as altering hierarchies of competence/power and using math to critically analyze the world.
  • Deficit views existed alongside descriptions of the importance of attending to biases, mathematical identities, and power structures.
  • Caring about students beyond their performance in math was a common theme, including providing support (by knowing if students are hungry or working long hours outside of school) to establishing trust and promoting engagement.
  • The access dimension of equity was prominent in pre-service teachers' thinking about equity, even more so than the identity dimension.
  • Perceptions of equity reflected preparation program experiences. Students from the Noyce program focusing on social justice tended to describe the importance of connecting mathematics to current issues in the real world, while students from the Noyce program with a focus on equity in participation in mathematics described establishing small groups and attending to patterns in participation.

From examination of beginning teachers' classroom teaching and their interviews (McGraw et al., 2024a), we found:

  • External pressures, including mandated curricula, pacing calendars, and standardized assessments, influenced teacher practice, leading them to rely on procedural, direct instruction.
  • Teachers consistently expressed concern for student well-being, actively sought to address material and instructional inequities, and demonstrated flexibility in supporting absent or struggling students.
  • While teachers were committed to principles of inclusive teaching, their classroom practices often reflected exclusive patterns of participation, including adherence to traditional Initiate Response Evaluate interaction models and verbal participation of a small subset of students.
  • Some teachers (those with prior learning of Complex Instruction) successfully implemented equitable participation structures. For many teachers, tensions emerged as they navigated grading policies and time constraints, which often undermined opportunities for extended mathematical discussions and equitable participation.
  • Participants were dissatisfied with the constraints imposed on them (e.g., pacing calendar), and wanted to create lessons that better aligned with what they had learned in their Noyce and teacher preparation programs. We propose that Noyce programs increase their focus on how to work toward equity within the constraints that the teachers will likely experience. We note that the teachers who implemented Complex Instruction had many experiences learning and teaching using CI in their preparation program, including working in real classrooms with teachers who were implementing CI. 

Participants experienced variable degrees of autonomy during the first years of teaching, but most experienced impactful constraints around standards, testing and pacing. With regard to competence, study participants describe their greatest challenges as addressing student knowledge gaps, absenteeism, differentiating instruction, and supporting student learning while meeting pacing/testing constraints. With respect to relatedness, participants interacted little with administrators, but met regularly with other teachers to discuss and plan for instruction. One of the Noyce programs provided participants with regular induction meetings and professional development experiences (e.g., action research), and study participants from this program spoke positively about the experience of mentorship and mutual support (Guerrero et al., 2024).

McGraw, R., Fernandes, A., Jarnutowski, B., & Wolfe, J. A. (2022). Preservice and beginning teachers’ perspectives on equity. In A. E. Lischka, E. B. Dyer, R. S. Jones, J. Lovett, J. Strayer, & S. Drown (Eds.), Proceedings of the forty-fourth annual meeting of the North American Chapter of the International Group for the Psychology of Mathematics Education (pp. 1243-1247). Nashville, TN: Middle Tennessee State University. http://www.pmena.org/pmenaproceedings/PMENA%2044%202022%20Proceedings.pdf

McGraw, R., Fernandes, A., Guerrero, S., & Wolfe, J. A. (2024a). The influence of context and culture on equity as access: The experience of beginning mathematics teachers in the United States. [Manuscript in preparation]

McGraw, R., Fernandes, A., Wolfe, J. A., & Jarnutowski, B. (2024b). Unpacking mathematics preservice teachers’ conceptions of equity. Mathematics Education Research Journal, 36, 645-670. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13394-023-00463-z
